Award.AbstractNarration:
The project contributes to the study of processes in disordered media (fractals), which have many applications in physics, chemistry, the biological sciences, and engineering. Diffusion processes in percolation clusters, vibrations of fractal objects, signal propagation in channels with random obstacles, electro-magnetic waves in fractal antennae, Rossby waves in oceanography, models of financial markets are just a few of many examples of such processes, for which the project will be creating new insights. The project integrates education and research with undergraduate students, in particular, REU summer undergraduate research projects, and incorporation of basic mathematical research in regular university courses. The broader impacts of the project include the following. The project will contribute to the development of human resources in science and engineering by teaching undergraduate and graduate students about frontiers of mathematical research, developing their understanding of new connections between real world and complicated mathematical abstractions based on concrete questions that are specifically tailored for this purpose, and also are natural parts of a broader research program. The project will include concrete steps to expand participation of underrepresented groups in mathematical research. All this will enhance overall infrastructure for research and education.

The existence and uniqueness of self-similar random walks, diffusions, and Dirichlet forms will be established for a wide class of spaces arising in various areas of mathematics, such as the limit sets of self-similar groups and Julia sets. Gaussian and non-Gaussian heat kernel estimates and Green's-function estimates will be obtained for such spaces. Furthermore, tools will be developed for the study of measurable Riemannian geometry of rough spaces without curvature bounds, but instead using symmetric diffusions, Dirichlet forms, and non-commutative probability. These ideas will be applied to the current problems of mathematical physics, such as magnetism and quantum waves on fractals, with the long term goal to understand the physically meaningful path integrals in fractal and more general non-smooth settings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal is to study the existence and uniqueness of self-similar random walks, diffusions, and Dirichlet forms for a wide class of spaces arising in various areas of mathematics, such as the limit sets of self-similar groups and Julia sets. Gaussian and non-Gaussian heat kernel estimates and Green's-function estimates are obtained for such spaces. Furthermore, tools are developed for the study of measurable Riemannian geometry of rough spaces without curvature bounds but instead using symmetric diffusions, Dirichlet forms, and non-commutative probability. These ideas are applied to the current problems of mathematical physics, such as magnetism and quantum waves on fractals, with the long-term goal to understand the physically meaningful path integrals in fractal and more general non-smooth settings.

During the work on the grant DMS 1613025 Random, Stochastic, and Self-Similar Equations project, the PI has completed:
* 23 works that are accepted or published,
* 6 reprints that are currently submitted.
Out of these 29 items, 24 are full-length research papers, 1 is an edited volume of conference proceedings, and 4 are refereed conference proceedings articles (containing new results). Several more papers supported by the PI where the PI is not a coauthor.  Many papers are published in major mathematics journals: Probability Theory and Related Fields, Stochastic Process. Appl., Calculus of Variations and PDE, Trans. Amer. Math. Soc., J. Funct. Anal., J. Fourier Anal. Appl., Mathematische Nachrichten, J. Noncommut. Geom., Math. Res. Lett., and in some of the leading mathematical physics journals: J. Phys. A: Math. Theor., J. Math. Phys., Lett. Math. Phys, Phys. Rev. Lett., Quant. Inf. Proc.

In addition, 3 Ph.D. students defended their Ph.D. theses, supported by the grant. The PI mentored and collaborated with a postdoctoral Fellow, who obtained a tenure-track research-oriented position at one of the top research universities in the US. In addition, PI collaborated on organizing 3 websites, was heavily involved in NSF REU Site work, and in many synergistic activities such as conference organizing, and collaboration with Applied Mathematics and other sciences (especially Physics, including on new aspects of quantum information theory). The PI also co-edited a volume of conference proceedings and is in the process of co-organizing the next conference in the Cornell Fractals series.


In recent years the PI conducted research in the following directions which involve,
but not limited to, Probabilistic, Spectral and Functional Analysis, Applied Mathematics
and Mathematical Physics:

(1) Symmetric Markov processes on singular spaces, including fractal spaces.

(2) Applied Mathematics in non-Lipschitz domains and on fractals.

(3) Mathematical Physics on fractals and graphs, including quantum information.

(4) Functional and spectral analysis on singular spaces, including fractal spaces, self-similar combinatorial and quantum graphs, and self-similar groups.


Last Modified: 03/03/2021
Modified by: Alexander Teplyaev
